subject: RE: [junit] Stop me from being bad: Functional testing w/junit OK?
msgSnippet: We have been using Junit purely at the API level for over a year and this has led to a much more stable product base.  Beginning with 0 Junit tests in place,
messageBody:
We have been using Junit purely at the API level for over a year and this has led to a much more stable product base. Beginning with 0 Junit tests in place, we had the choice of writing pure unit tests or approaching it at a higher level. In the interest of time, we chose to write at the same level that internal consumers and external customers would be doing, beginning with the APIs projected as being the 'most used'. In a perfect world, we would "do it all" but given time and resource constraints we went for the most 'bang for the buck' in this product cycle. While this wasn't intended to be a total replacement for pure unit tests, in theory if you cover all the exposed API's and their permutations of arguments, you are testing everything that can be reached by external means (we're not there yet, nor close :). Coupling this strategy with Continuous Integration using Cruise Control where the tests are run upon every code/testware push to cvs has greatly improved
confidence in product stability, not to mention that it has caught numerous bugs the moment they were introduced.

So, I see your strategy as very pragmatic but would also encourage in a secondary thread the development of pure unit tests, possibly beginning with new classes as they are created.

-----Original Message-----
From: jlindwall [mailto:jlindwall@...]
Sent: Wednesday, November 12, 2003 5:59 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Stop me from being bad: Functional testing w/junit OK?


Is it against the laws of nature to do something more then unit
testing with junit?

I have a heirarchy of objects that implement a common interface (an
SPI if you will). Each object has a "normal" life cycle that
consists of the following methods being called: beginFile(), print(),
endFile(). The result of these calls is a file generated on disk.

I guess that this is not unit testing because I'm not testing a
single method's actions. I want to call this sequence of methods and
then compare the generated files to golden masters.

FURTHERMORE, I'd like to use reflection to perform these steps on
each class in the heirarchy so it will automatically test new
implementations as they are added to the tree.

Is it inappropriate to use junit in this way? Is there a better way?

Thanks!
